sen.e: The sake produced in Kyoto included those which would today be considered as falling under mislabeling or misleading representation of products, such as "shoka gozenshu (sake for the feudal lord for families)", "御前酒" (which can be read as "gozenshu" but uses a different Chinese character for "zen" from the actual gozenshu), and "goyoshu (sake especially made for someone in high rank)", as many sake breweries, which tried to take advantage of "Kenbishi" by placing on sake barrels brand names that are confusingly similar to the gozenshu for the shogun family, appeared.

sen.j: 御膳酒は、それぞれの藩主の方針によって、将軍家と同じ伊丹酒や、そうでなくても同じ地方である摂泉十二郷の酒を御膳酒に指定した大名もいれば、自領の産業育成のため、国許（くにもと）特産の酒を御膳酒に指定した大名もいる。
sen.e: The selection of gozenshu differed according to the lord of each domain; for gozenshu, some daimyo selected Itami sake like the shogun family, or at least the sake from the same Sessen-juni-go (the twelve sake brewing districts in Settsu Province and Izumi Province shipping for Edo) where the Itami sake was produced, and some others selected the sake which was the local specialty of the hometown, for the purpose of industrial development of his own domain.

sen.j: 後者の場合、御膳酒は藩造酒（はんぞうしゅ）の最高級品であったが、藩造酒じたいの醸造技術が拙く、数々の努力にもかかわらずついに他国に通用するに至らなかった藩もあるので、そのような場合、藩主は藩の財政改善のため、味覚的に多少の我慢をして飲んでいたことになる。
sen.e: In the latter case, although the gozenshu was the top quality product of the sake brewed by the clan, sometimes the sake brewed by the clan was in itself the result of poor brewing techniques despite many efforts, and not good enough to be eventually sold to other domains; in such case, the lord was drinking it with some tolerance in terms of the taste, so as to improve the finances of his domain.

sen.e: Goyo zakaya is said to have begun with the first Mataemon KAMENOMORI, who was of the Nara school of sake, which observed the tradition of soboshu (sake brewed in major temples) that was known as a famous sake-brewing district before Itami became famous; KAMENOMORI was introduced by Munenori YAGYU to Masamune DATE, who ordered KAMENOMORI the work of jonai-zume-onsake-goyo (making of sake especially for the feudal lord inside the castle) in Sendai Domain in 1608.
